StringWithMarkup.String: According to compiled results of the US Food and Drug Administration's pesticide residue monitoring programs (including the Total Diet Study) for fiscal years 1978-1986, fenvalerate has been detected as a pesticide residue in American foods(1,2); the frequency of occurrence or concentrations of fenvalerate detected were not reported(SRC). During a 5-yr period from 1982-1986, the US FDA's Los Angeles District Laboratory analyzed 19,581 samples of domestic and imported food and feed commodities for pesticide residues(3); fenvalerate was detected in 25 samples at concentrations of 0.05-1.0 ppm(3). For fiscal years 1988 and 1989, 27,065 food samples were collected and analyzed for pesticide residues by 10 state laboratories (CA, NY, FL, IN, MA, MI, NC, OR, VA and WI)(4); fenvalerate was detected in 54 samples (concentrations not reported)(4). According to compiled results of the US Food and Drug Administration's pesticide residue monitoring programs in domestic infant and adult foods for fiscal years 1985-1991, fenvalerate was detected as a pesticide residue in 11 of 2,464 apple samples, maximum residue 0.19 ppm and in 1 of 571 pear samples, maximum residue 0.08 ppm(5). Fenvalerate was not detected in 234 items making up diets of 8 population groups as a result of an FDA Total Diet Study conducted from July 1986 through April 1991(6). A US Food and Drug Administration 1992-1993 survey of 710 domestic and 949 imported pears resulted in detection of fenvalerate in two domestic samples at a maximum concentration of 0.08 ppm and one imported sample at 0.05 ppm; a survey of 1,219 domestic and 144 imported tomatoes resulted in detection of fenvalerate in three domestic samples at a trace concentration; it was not detected in imported tomato samples(7). A US Food and Drug Administration 1993-1994 survey of 769 domestic and 1,062 imported apples resulted in detection of fenvalerate in one imported sample at 0.81 ppm; it was not detected in domestic samples(8).

Reference: (1) IARC; IARC Monographs on the Evaluation of Carcinogen Risks to Humans. Lyon, France: World Health Organization 53: 309-28 (1991)
(2) Juhler RK et al; J AOAC Internat 82: 337-58 (1999)
(3) Parveen Z et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 74: 170-6 (2005)

(4) WHO/FAO; WHO/FAO Data Sheets on Pesticides. No. 90. Fenvalerate. WHO/PCS/DS/96.90, July 1996. 3.8. Residues in Food. World Health Organization. Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations. Available at https://www.inchem.org/documents/pds/pds/pest90_e.htm#3.8 as of Jun 17, 2008.
(5) Akiyama Y et al; J AOAC Internat 85: 692-703 (2002)

StringWithMarkup.String: Of a total of 946 samples analyzed in the 1984-1989 Canadian national surveillance program, 7 were found to contain fenvalerate residues, at levels of 0.02-0.096 mg/kg(1); most were in pears (6/114 samples) and one in lettuce (1/11 samples)(1). In Sweden, 163 of 165 samples of imported fruit and vegetables contained residues up to 0.2 mg/kg(1); one had a residue of 0.54 mg/kg(1). As a result of a Danish survey of food commodities conducted from January 1995 to December 1996, fenvalerate was not detected in unspecified fruits and vegetables and cereals(2). As a result of food monitoring studies conducted in Karachi, Pakistan from 2000-2003, fenvalerate residues were detected in 15 of 206 samples of 27 market basket vegetables, with positive detections were reported in onion, mint, salad, spinach, chillies, french bean, cucumber, tomato, cabbage, and cauliflower(3). Four samples exceeding the FAO/WHO limit(3) of acceptable daily intake of 0-0.02 mg/kg body weight established in 1986(4). Fenvalerate residues were reported in 765 agricultural products (478 domestic, 287 imported) in the Hyogo Prefecture Japan, sampled from April 1995 through March 2000); 12 of 291 domestic lettuce samples positive, 4 at <0.01 ug/g, 3 at <0.05 ug/g, 3 at <0.1 ug/g, 2 at <0.5 ug/g; 5 of 106 Japanese persimmon samples positive, 2 at <0.01 ug/g, 1 at <0.05 ug/g, 1 at <0.1 ug/g, 1 at <0.5 ug/g(5). Fenvaerlate was detected in 4 of 55 imported broccoli samples, 2 at <0.01 ug/g, 2 at <0.5 ug/g(5).

Reference: (1) Sukul P; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 55: 562-67 (1995)
(2) Jain RK; Sci Total Environ 187: 253-5 (1996)

StringWithMarkup.String: Fenvalerate residues in green gram (Vigna radiata) foliage, a staple food crop of India, were 13.1, 6.8, 2.6. and 1.7 ppm at 1 hr, 5, 10, and 15 days, respectively, following commercial application, corresponding to a half-life of 5.0 days and safe waiting period of 19 days(1). Levels in okra fruits remaining following spraying with low application of 300 ml/ha (ppm, time after treatment) were: 1.38, 1 hr; 1.09, 1 day; 0.40, 3 days; 0.28, 7 days; 0.10, 10 days; not detected, 25 days(2). At medium application of 375 ml/ha, residues were (ppm, time after treatment): 2.76, 1 hr; 1.31, 1 day; 0.69, 3 days; 0.51, 7 days; 0.02, 10 days; not detected, 25 days(2). At high application of 500 mL/ha, residues were (ppm, time after treatment): 4.54, 1 hr; 2.52, 1 day; 1.27, 3 days; 0.67, 7 days; 0.04, 10 days; not detected, 25 days(2). These results suggest a waiting period of 10 days before residues fall below the maximum allowable residue limit of 0.2 ppm(2).

Reference: (1) Mukerjee I, Gopal M; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 56: 381-8 (1996)
(2) Rogers WM et al; J AOAC Internat 78: 614-31 (1995)
(3) Dogheim SM et al; J AOAC Internat 84: 519-31 (2001)

StringWithMarkup.String: The average fenvalerate concentration in farmgate samples of eggplant was 0.16 ug/g, sampled in India(1). As a result of a US ten-year study of ready-to-eat foods conducted from 1982-1991, fenvalerate was detected in canned green beans, 1 sample, 0.0410 ug/g and in canned spinach 1 sample, 0.0570 ug/g; samples were of 37 market baskets, each containing 234 food items representing 5,000 food types in American diets(2). Fenvalerate was analyzed for in 1,579 Egyptian fruit and vegetable samples in 1996; it was detected in one cucumber sample, concentration of 0.14 mg/kg(3).

StringWithMarkup.String: EXPERIMENTAL: Two Holstein cows were treated with 0.5 g of fenvalerate per cow in three consecutive topical treatments at 14-day intervals(1); residues in whole milk were at a max 6 hr after treatment and declined to less than 0.2 ug/L over 21 days(1); only 0.03-0.06% of applied fenvalerate appeared in the milk as the intact insecticide(1). Section.Description: Scientific articles associated with this compound.  Some chemical-literature associations in this section are provided by data contributors or derived from MeSH annotations, as explained in Kim et al., J. Cheminform. 2016, 8, 32.  This section also provides the lists of chemicals, genes/proteins, and diseases, that are co-mentioned in scientific articles, as described in Zaslavsky et al., Front. Res. Metr. Anal., 2021, 6, 689059.

The consolidated references include literature data from all sources including Springer Nature, Thieme Chemistry, Wiley, Nature journals, depositor provided citations, and NLM curated PubMed citations.
The NLM Curated PubMed Citations section links to all PubMed records that are tagged with the same MeSH term that has been associated with a particular compound.

Literature references related to scientific contents from Springer Nature journals and books. These references have been ranked automatically by an algorithm which calculates the relevance for each substance in a Springer Nature document. It is based on: (1) the TF-IDF, adapted to chemical structures, (2) location information in the text (e.g. title, abstract, keywords), and (3) the document size.  Springer Nature aims to provide only highly qualitative and relevant content but references of lower relevance aren't withheld as they might contain also very useful information.

Literature references related to scientific contents from Thieme Chemistry journals and books. The Thieme Chemistry content within this section is provided under a CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 license (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/), unless otherwise stated.
Literature references related to scientific contents from Wiley journals and books.

Chemical co-occurrences in literature highlight chemicals mentioned together in scientific articles. This may suggest that an important relationship exists between the two. Please note that this content is not human curated. It is generated by text-mining algorithms that can be fooled such that a co-occurrence may be happenstance or a casual mention. Reference.Name: EPA SRS List Classification
Reference.Description: Substance Registry Services (SRS) is the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) central system for information about substances that are tracked or regulated by EPA or other sources. It is a resource for basic information about chemicals, biological organisms, and other substances of interest to EPA and its state and tribal partners. SRS makes it possible to identify which EPA data systems, environmental statutes, or other sources have information about a substance and which synonym is used by that system or statute.

Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.
